p: Human malaria is a group of four infections caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Plasmodium and transmitted by anopheline mosquitoes. On a global scale, practically all cases of malaria are caused by either P. falciparum or P. vivax. The former is the predominant of the two ( ca 90%). The share of infections caused by human parasites P. malariae and P. ovale is negligible. Humans occasionally become infected with Plasmodium species that normally infect animals, such as P. knowlesi. As of yet, there are no reports of human–mosquito–human transmission of such zoonotic species of malaria [ 1]. Particular parasite species have their specific strategies for survival [ 2], as well as their own features of pathology, epidemiology, public health significance, and amenability to control.
